facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 49 of 1961 was filed by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 11, 1960 of the Bombay High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 320 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 49 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 11, 1960, of the Bombay High Court in Civil Revision Application No. 320 of 1959.

facts.text: The appellants executed a rent note on September 11, 1942 under which they occupied the premises in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: On September 11, 1942, the appellants had executed a rent numbere, under which they were in occupation of the premises in dispute. The period of the tenancy was 15 years, and it expired by efflux of time on, March 14, 1957.

facts.text: The tenancy period was 15 years and expired on March 14, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The period of the tenancy was 15 years, and it expired by efflux of time on, March 14, 1957. The landlord thereupon filed a suit on April 25, 1957, for possession of the premises, in the Court of the Joint Civil Judge  Junior Division , Erandol.

facts.text: The respondent landlord filed a suit for possession on April 25, 1957 in the Court of the Joint Civil Judge Junior Division, Erandol.

anchor.surface_text: The landlord thereupon filed a suit on April 25, 1957, for possession of the premises, in the Court of the Joint Civil Judge  Junior Division , Erandol. Meanwhile, under s. 6 of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947,  to be called the Act, in this judgment , a numberification was issued, applying Part II of the Act to the area where the property is situated.

facts.text: A notification was issued under section 6 of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 applying Part II of the Act to the area where the property is situated.

anchor.surface_text: Meanwhile, under s. 6 of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947,  to be called the Act, in this judgment , a numberification was issued, applying Part II of the Act to the area where the property is situated. The appellants claimed protection of s. 12 in Part 11 of the Act, which deprived the landlord of the right of possession under certain circumstances.

facts.text: Government of Bombay issued Notification on 16th August 1958 applying Part II of the Bombay Rents Act.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the plaintiffs suit for possession of the suit property is maintainable in view of the Notification issued by the Government of Bombay on 16th August, 1958, applying Part II of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act?

facts.text: Appellants claimed protection of section 12 in Part II of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants claimed protection of s. 12 in Part 11 of the Act, which deprived the landlord of the right of possession under certain circumstances. The Civil Judge framed three preliminary Issues, which were as follows Whether this Court has jurisdiction to try the suit?

facts.text: Civil Judge framed three preliminary issues including jurisdiction and maintainability in view of the Notification.

anchor.surface_text: The Civil Judge framed three preliminary Issues, which were as follows Whether this Court has jurisdiction to try the suit? Whether the plaintiffs suit for possession of the suit property is maintainable in view of the Notification issued by the Government of Bombay on 16th August, 1958, applying Part II of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act? If number, what order should be passed? What order?.

facts.text: Civil Judge decided the three preliminary issues against the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: These Issues were decided against the appellants. They filed a revision petition before the High Court of Bombay, which was dismissed by the order under appeal.

facts.text: Appellants filed revision petition in Civil Revision Application No. 320 of 1959 before Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: They filed a revision petition before the High Court of Bombay, which was dismissed by the order under appeal. Naik, J., who heard the revision, followed a previous Full Bench ruling of the Bombay High Court reported in Nilkanth Ramachandra v. Rasiktal  1 .

facts.text: Bombay High Court dismissed the revision by Naik J. on August 11, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: This is a tenants appeal, with the special leave of this Court, against an order of Naik, J., of the High Court of Bombay in Civil Revision Application No. 320 of 1959, by which he disallowed certain pleas raised by the appellants.

facts.text: Naik J. followed Full Bench ruling in Nilkanth Ramachandra v. Rasiktal (1949) 51 Bom. L.R. 280 holding s.12 prospective.

anchor.surface_text: Naik, J., who heard the revision, followed a previous Full Bench ruling of the Bombay High Court reported in Nilkanth Ramachandra v. Rasiktal  1 . In that case, Chagla, C. J.  Gajendragadkar and Tendolkar, JJ., companycurring  had held that s. 12 of the Act was prospective and did number apply to pending cases.

facts.text: Supreme Court approved Bombay Full Bench in Chandrasingh Manibhai v. Surjit Lal Sadhamal Chhabda (1951 S.C.R. 221).

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was also placed by Naik, J., on the decision of this Court in Chandrasingh Manibhai v. Surjit Lal Sadhamal Chhabda  2 , where the opinion of the Full Bench of the Bombay High Court was approved.

facts.text: The judgment was delivered by Hidayatullah J. on April 21, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. April 21. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is a tenants appeal, with the special leave of this Court, against an order of Naik, J., of the High Court of Bombay in Civil Revision Application No. 320 of 1959,

facts.text: Bombay High Court ruled that s.12 of the Act was prospective and did not apply to pending suits.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, ruled that s. 12 was prospective in character and did number apply to pending suits or proceedings.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal and answered the two preliminary issues in favour of the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The companyclusion must follow that the present suit cannot be decreed in favour of the respondent. The decisions of the High Court and the Court of First Instance are thus erroneous, and must be set aside. In the result, the appeal is allowed, and the two preliminary Issues are answered in favour of the appellants.

facts.text: Judgment of Civil Judge was stayed under orders of Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Under the orders of this Court, the judgment of the Civil Judge was stayed. The suit will number be decided in companyformity with our judgment.

facts.text: Bombay Rent Restriction Act, 1939 and Bombay Rents, Hotel Rates and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1944 were repealed by s.50 of the 1947 Act.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was number the first to be passed on the subject of companytrol of houses, etc. Previously, there were two other Acts in force in the State of Bombay, viz., the Bombay Rent Restriction Act, 1939 and the Bombay Rents, Hotel Rates and Lodging House Rates  Control  Act, 1944. By s. 50 of the Act, these Acts were repealed.

facts.text: Appellants are tenants and respondent is landlord.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This is a tenants appeal, with the special leave of this Court, against an order of Naik, J., of the High Court of Bombay in Civil Revision Application No. 320 of 1959, by which he disallowed certain pleas raised by the appellants. The respondent is the landlord.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that s.12(1) applies to pending suits when Part II comes into force.

anchor.surface_text: The point of time when the sub-section will operate is when the decree for recovery of possession would have to be passed. Thus, the language of the sub- section applies equally to suits pending when Part 11 companyes into force and those to be filed subsequently.

facts.text: Appellants as statutory tenants fulfil requirements of s.12(1) by expressing readiness to pay standard rent.

anchor.surface_text: The tenants, in the present case, have expressed their readiness and willingness to pay, and it is clear that they fulfil the requirements of sub-s.  1  of S. 12, and the landlord is, therefore, number entitled to the relief of possession.

facts.text: Part II of the Act was extended to the area after the suit was filed while pending.

anchor.surface_text: Part II came to be extended to this area by the numberification, and after that extension, Parts 1, 11 and IV of the Act began to apply, while the suit was pending.

facts.text: First proviso to s.50 provides for transfer and continuation of pending suits under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that all suits and proceedings between a landlord and a tenant relating to the recovery or fixing of rent or possession of any premises to which the provisions of Part 11 apply which are pending in any Court, shall be transferred to and companytinued before the Courts which would have jurisdiction to try such suits or proceedings under this Act or shall be companytinued in such Courts, as the case may be, and all the provisions of this Act and the rules made thereunder shall apply to all such suits and proceedings.

facts.text: Tenant definition includes person continuing in possession after tenancy determination.

anchor.surface_text: The word tenant is defined in the Act to include number only a tenant, whose tenancy subsists but also any person remaining, after the determination of the lease, in possession with or without the assent of the landlord.

anchor.surface_text: Section 12 of the Act reads as follows 12.  1  A landlord shall number be entitled to the recovery of possession of any premises so long as the tenant pays, or is ready and willing to pay, the amount of the standard rent and permitted increases, if any, and observes and performs the other conditions of the tenancy, in so far as they are consistent with the provisions of this Act.

concepts.unlisted_description: Protection against eviction if tenant pays standard rent

anchor.surface_text: No suit for recovery of possession shall be instituted by a landlord against a tenant on the ground of number-payment of the standard rent or permitted increases due, until the expiration of one month next after notice in writing of the demand of the standard rent or permitted increases has been served upon the tenant in the manner provided in section 106 of the Transfer of Property Act, 1882.

By sub-ss.  1  and  2  of the second section, which dealt with the extent of the application of the Act, it was provided that Parts I and IV of the Act shall extend to the pre-Reorganisation State of Bombay, excluding transferred territories, and Parts II and III shall extend respectively to the areas specified in Schs. I and II to the Act,

anchor.surface_text: It is true that s. 51 is framed as a proviso upon preceding sections. But it is also true that the latter half of it, though in form a proviso, is in substance a fresh enactment, adding to and number merely qualifying that which goes before... The effect of an excepting or qualifying proviso... is to except out of the preceding portion of the enactment, or to qualify something enacted therein,

holdings.text: Section 12(1) of the Act applies to suits pending when Part II comes into force, as it operates at the time the decree for possession is to be passed.

anchor.surface_text: The point of time when the sub-section will operate is when the decree for recovery of possession would have to be passed. Thus, the language of the sub- section applies equally to suits pending when Part 11 comes into force and those to be filed subsequently.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.12(1) enacts rule of decision at decree stage; language applies equally to pending and future suits; distinguishes prior cases on subs.(2)&(3); protective statute given retrospective effect where intent apparent.

holdings.text: Previous decisions holding s.12 prospective concerned only sub-sections (2) and (3), not sub-section (1).

anchor.surface_text: Both the Bombay High Court and this Court had, on the previous occasions, observed that s. 12 of the Act was prospective. In those cases, the learned Judges were concerned with the interpretation of sub ss. 2 and 3 only, which...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior judgments dealt with subs.(2)&(3) which were prospective; sub.(1) not interpreted; section parts can differ in operation.

holdings.text: The definition of 'tenant' includes statutory tenants continuing in possession after tenancy determination, entitling them to s.12(1) protection.

anchor.surface_text: The word tenant is defined in the Act to include not only a tenant, whose tenancy subsists but also any person remaining, after the determination of the lease, in possession with or without the assent of the landlord.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of statutory definition to facts; appellants as statutory tenants within scope.

holdings.text: Appellants fulfil requirements of s.12(1) as they expressed readiness and willingness to pay standard rent.

anchor.surface_text: The tenants, in the present case, have expressed their readiness and willingness to pay, and it is clear that they fulfil the requirements of sub-s. 1 of S. 12, and the landlord is, therefore, not entitled to the relief of possession.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tenants' expressed willingness satisfies condition in s.12(1); applies to statutory tenants.

holdings.text: Landlord not entitled to decree for possession; suit not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: The conclusion must follow that the present suit cannot be decreed in favour of the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from application of s.12(1) to facts; tenant complies.

holdings.text: Decisions of High Court and trial court erroneous and set aside; appeal allowed; preliminary issues answered in favour of appellants.

anchor.surface_text: The decisions of the High Court and the Court of First Instance are thus erroneous, and must be set aside. In the result, the appeal is allowed, and the two preliminary Issues are answered in favour of the appellants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts wrongly held s.12 prospective for sub.(1); s.12(1) bars decree.

holdings.text: Question of first proviso to s.50 need not be decided.

anchor.surface_text: But, in our opinion, they need not be considered in this case, in view of what we have decided on the second point.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Second contention (s.12(1)) sufficient to dispose case; arguments interesting but unnecessary.

precedents.citation: Nilkanth Ramachandra v. Rasiktal 1 1949 51 Bom. L.R. 280

anchor.surface_text: Nilkanth Ramachandra v. Rasiktal  1 . In that case, Chagla, C. J.  Gajendragadkar and Tendolkar, JJ., companycurring  had held that s. 12 of the Act was prospective and did number apply to pending cases. Reliance was also placed by Naik, J., on the decision of this Court in Chandrasingh Manibhai v. Surjit Lal Sadhamal Chhabda  2 , where the opinion

precedents.cited_proposition: s. 12 of the Act was prospective and did not apply to pending cases

precedents.citation: Chandrasingh Manibhai v. Surjit Lal Sadhamal Chhabda 2 1951 S.C.R. 221

anchor.surface_text: Reliance was also placed by Naik, J., on the decision of this Court in Chandrasingh Manibhai v. Surjit Lal Sadhamal Chhabda  2 , where the opinion of the Full Bench of the Bombay High Court was approved.  1   1949  51 Bom. L.R. 280.  2  1951 S.C.R. 221. Two Questions have been raised in this appeal, and they are  1  whether by virtue of the first proviso to s. 50 of the Act, all the provisions of Part 11 including s. 12 were number expressly made applicable to all suits and  2  whether by virtue of s. 12 1  of the Act, which applied independently by the extension of the Act to the area where the property is situate, the suit was number rendered incompetent and the landlord deprived of his remedy of possession.

precedents.case_name: Chandrasingh Manibhai v. Surjit Lal Sadhamal Chhabda
precedents.cited_proposition: opinion of the Full Bench of the Bombay High Court that s. 12 was prospective was approved

precedents.citation: Rhondda Urban Council v. Taff Vale Railway 1 1909 A.C. 253, 258

anchor.surface_text: He relies upon the following observations of Lord Loreburn, L. C., in Rhondda Urban Council v. Taff Vale Railway  1 , where a pro- viso to s. 51 of the Railway Clauses Consolidation Act, 1845, was under companysideration It is true that s. 51 is framed as a proviso upon preceding sections. But it is also true that the latter half of it, though in form a proviso, is in substance a fresh enactment, adding to and number merely qualifying that which goes before., and companytends that the latter portion of the proviso, in question, being a substantive enactment, companyprehends number only those suits which were pending on the date of repeal but also those cases, which came within the language of the latter part of the proviso, whenever the Act was extended to new areas.

precedents.case_name: Rhondda Urban Council v. Taff Vale Railway
precedents.cited_proposition: the latter half of it, though in form a proviso, is in substance a fresh enactment, adding to and not merely qualifying that which goes before
precedents.cited_holding: It is true that s. 51 is framed as a proviso upon preceding sections. But it is also true that the latter half of it, though in form a proviso, is in substance a fresh enactment, adding to and number merely qualifying that which goes before.

precedents.citation: Mullins v. Treasurer of Surrey 1 1880 5 Q.B.D. 170, 173

anchor.surface_text: He also relies upon the following observations of Lush, J., in Mullins v. Treasurer of Surrey  1  When one finds a proviso to a section, the natural presumption is that, but for the proviso, the enacting part of the section would have included the subject-matter of the proviso. The law with regard to provisos is well-settled and well- understood. As a general rule, a proviso is added to an enactment to qualify or create an exception to what is in the enactment, and ordinarily, a proviso is number interpreted as stating a general rule.

precedents.cited_proposition: When one finds a proviso to a section, the natural presumption is that, but for the proviso, the enacting part of the section would have included the subject-matter of the proviso
precedents.cited_holding: When one finds a proviso to a section, the natural presumption is that, but for the proviso, the enacting part of the section would have included the subject-matter of the proviso.

precedents.citation: Fitzgerald v. Champneys 2 1861 2 J. H. 3170 E.R. 958

anchor.surface_text: It was observed by Wood, V. C., in Fitzgerald v. Champneys 2  that saving clauses are seldom used to companystrue Acts. These clauses are introduced into Acts which repeal others, to safe. guard rights which, but for the savings, would be lost. The proviso here saves pending suits and proceedings, and further enacts that suits and proceedings then pending are to be transferred to the Courts designated in the Act and are to companytinue under the Act and any or all the provisions of the Act are to apply to them. The learned Solicitor-General companytends that the savings clause enacted by the proviso, even if treated as substantive law, must be taken to  1   1880  5 Q.B.D. 170, 173.  2   1861  2 J. H. 3170 E.R. 958.

precedents.cited_proposition: saving clauses are seldom used to construe Acts
precedents.cited_holding: saving clauses are seldom used to companystrue Acts

anchor.surface_text: The decisions of the High Court and the Court of First Instance are thus erroneous, and must be set aside. In the result, the appeal is allowed, and the two preliminary Issues are answered in favour of the appellants. Under the orders of this Court, the judgment of the Civil Judge was stayed.

anchor.surface_text: The point of time when the sub-section will operate is when the decree for recovery of possession would have to be passed. Thus, the language of the sub- section applies equally to suits pending when Part 11 comes into force and those to be filed subsequently.

The decisions of the High Court and the Court of First Instance are thus erroneous, and must be set aside. In the result, the appeal is allowed, and the two preliminary Issues are answered in favour of the appellants. Under the orders of this Court, the judgment of the Civil Judge was stayed.

anchor.surface_text: The tenants, in the present case, have expressed their readiness and willingness to pay, and it is clear that they fulfil the requirements of sub-s. 1 of S. 12, and the landlord is, therefore, not entitled to the relief of possession.
